javadoc:
Class for managing and sharing thread pools. The GThreadPool is simplified version of the ThreadPoolExecutor, which can be confusing to use with its many configuration parameters. The GThreadPool has a simple behavior that is controlled by only two configuration parameters - the minimum number of threads and the maximum number of threads.

The simple behavior for when new tasks are submitted:
1) If there any idle threads, use that thread.
2) If all existing threads are busy and the number of threads is less than max threads, add a new thread and use it.
3) if all threads are busy and there are max number of threads, queue the item until a thread becomes free.

The simple behavior for when tasks are completed by a thread:
1) If there are tasks in the queue, start processing a new item in the newly freed thread.
2) if there are more threads that min threads, allow this thread to die if no new jobs arrive before the "KEEP ALIVE" time expires which is currently 15 seconds.
3) if there are min threads or less, allow this thread to wait forever for a new job to arrive.

methods.name: getPrivateThreadPool
methods.comment: Creates a new, private thread pool with the given name.

params.name: name
params.comment: the name of the thread pool

return.comment: a private GThreadPool with the given name.

methods.name: getSharedThreadPool
methods.comment:
Returns a shared GThreadPool.  If a shared GThreadPool already exists with the given name,
 it is returned.  Otherwise, a new shared GThreadPool is created and returned.

return.comment: a shared GThreadPool with the given name.

methods.name: setMaxThreadCount
methods.comment:
Sets the max number of threads to use in this thread pool.  The default is the number
 of processors + 1.

params.name: maxThreadCount
params.comment: the maximum number of threads to use in this thread pool.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.
@return the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.
methods.name: getMinThreadCount
methods.comment: Returns the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.

return.comment: the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.

methods.javadoc:
Sets the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.
@param minThreadCount the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.
methods.name: setMinThreadCount
methods.comment: Sets the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.

params.name: minThreadCount
params.comment: the minimum number of threads to keep alive in this thread pool.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the maximum number of threads to use in this thread pool.
@return the maximum number of threads to use in this thread pool.
methods.name: getMaxThreadCount
methods.comment: Returns the maximum number of threads to use in this thread pool.

return.comment: the maximum number of threads to use in this thread pool.

methods.javadoc:
Submits a FutreTask to be executed by a thread in this thread pool.
@param futureTask the future task to be executed.
methods.name: submit
methods.comment: Submits a FutreTask to be executed by a thread in this thread pool.

params.name: futureTask
params.comment: the future task to be executed.

methods.name: submit
methods.comment: Submits a runnable to be executed by this thread pool.

methods.name: submit
methods.comment: Submits a runnable to be executed by this thread pool.

params.name: result
params.comment: the result to be returned after the runnable has executed.

methods.name: submit
methods.comment: Submits a callable to be executed by this thread pool.

methods.javadoc:
Returns true if this is not a shared thread pool.
@return true if this is not a shared thread pool.
methods.name: isPrivate
methods.comment: Returns true if this is not a shared thread pool.

return.comment: true if this is not a shared thread pool.

methods.javadoc:
Returns the {@link Executor} used by this thread pool.

Note: normal usage of this thread pool contraindicates accessing the executor of this pool. For managing your own jobs, you should use the method on this class directly. The intent of this method is to provide access to the executor so that it may be passed to other asynchronous APIs, such as the {@link CompletableFuture}. @return the executor
methods.name: getExecutor
methods.comment:
Returns the Executor used by this thread pool.
 
 Note: normal usage of this thread pool contraindicates accessing the executor of 
 this pool.  For managing your own jobs, you should use the method on this class directly.
 The intent of this method is to provide access to the executor so that it may be 
 passed to other asynchronous APIs, such as the CompletableFuture.

name: GThreadPool
comment:
Class for managing and sharing thread pools. The GThreadPool is simplified version of the
 ThreadPoolExecutor, which can be confusing to use with its many configuration parameters.
 The GThreadPool has a simple behavior that is controlled by only two configuration parameters -
 the minimum number of threads and the maximum number of threads.
 
 The simple behavior for when new tasks are submitted:
  1) If there any idle threads, use that thread.
  2) If all existing threads are busy and the number of threads is less than max threads, add a 
     new thread and use it.
  3) if all threads are busy and there are max number of threads, queue the item until a thread
     becomes free.
 
 The simple behavior for when tasks are completed by a thread:
  1) If there are tasks in the queue, start processing a new item in the newly freed thread.
  2) if there are more threads that min threads, allow this thread to die if no new 
     jobs arrive before
     the "KEEP ALIVE" time expires which is currently 15 seconds.
  3) if there are min threads or less, allow this thread to wait forever for a new job 
     to arrive.
